t: Proverbs 13
A*pn wise son heeds his father’s instruction, but*ld a mocker does not respond to rebukes.
From*pn the fruit of their lips people enjoy good things, but*ld the unfaithful have an appetite for violence.
Those*pn who guard their lips preserve their lives, but*ld those who speak rashly will come to ruin.
A*pn sluggard’s appetite is never filled, but*ld the desires of the diligent are fully satisfied.
The*pn righteous hate what is false, but*ld the wicked make themselves a stench and*ld bring shame on themselves.
Righteousness*pn guards the person of integrity, but*ld wickedness overthrows the sinner.
One*pn person pretends to be rich, yet has nothing; another*ld pretends to be poor, yet has great wealth.
A*pn person’s riches may ransom their life, but*ld the poor cannot respond to threatening rebukes.
The*pn light of the righteous shines brightly, but*ld the lamp of the wicked is snuffed out.
Where*pn there is strife, there is pride, but*ld wisdom is found in those who take advice.
Dishonest*pn money dwindles away, but*ld whoever gathers money little by little makes it grow.
Hope*pn deferred makes the heart sick, but*ld a longing fulfilled is a tree of life.
Whoever*pn scorns instruction will pay for it, but*ld whoever respects a command is rewarded.
The*pn teaching of the wise is a fountain of life, turning*ld a person from the snares of death.
Good*pn judgment wins favor, but*ld the way of the unfaithful leads to their destruction.
All*pn who are prudent act with knowledge, but*ld fools expose their folly.
A*pn wicked messenger falls into trouble, but*ld a trustworthy envoy brings healing.
Whoever*pn disregards discipline comes to poverty and shame, but*ld whoever heeds correction is honored.
A*pn longing fulfilled is sweet to the soul, but*ld fools detest turning from evil.
Walk*pn with the wise and become wise, for*ld a companion of fools suffers harm.
Trouble*pn pursues the sinner, but*ld the righteous are rewarded with good things.
A*pn good person leaves an inheritance for their children’s children, but*ld a sinner’s wealth is stored up for the righteous.
An*pn unplowed field produces food for the poor, but*ld injustice sweeps it away.
Whoever*pn spares the rod hates their children, but*ld the one who loves their children is careful to discipline them.
The*pn righteous eat to their hearts’ content, but*ld the stomach of the wicked goes hungry.
